page.title: 19WHEATHAMPSTEAD HISTORY
page.content: The Devils Dyke is an ancient battlefield in Wheathampstead where lots of people live today.The entrance to the Dyke is part of a city built in the 1st century B.C. A set of gates were presented by the Rt Hon Lord Brocket to commemorate their majesties King George VI and Queen Elizabeth's coronation on the 12th May 1937.It was probably here that Julius Ceasar defeated the British King called Cassivellavinus in 54 B.C.Today the Dyke is used for playing in and dumping rubbish in there.There are more trees in there to make it easier to get up the steep hills.There are some blank spaces where you just slide down the hills.It is rich with holly trees and there are a few stinging nettles.
